keyTakeAways: More than half of the top teams in England and Wales now have American ownership.
U.S. investors see British soccer as a more affordable and prestigious alternative to American sports franchises like those in the NFL and NBA.
Celebrity investors such as Will Ferrell, Snoop Dogg, LeBron James, and Ryan Reynolds have invested in British clubs, increasing public interest and commercial appeal.
The popularity of the TV show 'Ted Lasso' has significantly boosted American interest in British soccer.
American ownership has led to increased commercialization, including greater investment in women's football and improved stadium infrastructure.
While some fans are concerned about changes to the game, most support American ownership due to modernization and improved fan experience.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A growing trend of American investment in British soccer teams has emerged, with more than half of the teams in England and Wales now having some form of American ownership. This trend is driven by the affordability of British clubs compared to American sports franchises like those in the NFL and NBA. High-profile American celebrities such as Will Ferrell, Snoop Dogg, LeBron James, Ryan Reynolds, and Tom Brady have invested in clubs like Leeds, Swansea, Liverpool, Wrexham, and Birmingham City. Celebrity involvement has also been amplified by the success of the TV show 'Ted Lasso,' which has boosted American interest. Experts note that American ownership has introduced commercial growth, increased investment in women's football, and improved stadium infrastructure. While some fans in Britain express concerns about potential changes to the game, most support American ownership due to modernization and enhanced fan experience. The U.S. audience for British soccer is large, with 40 million fans, and this trend is expected to grow further with the upcoming World Cup hosted in North America.
title: Why are so many rich Americans investing in British soccer teams?
